sn5.1:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn5.1:4.3: Then the nun Āḷavikā got dressed in the morning and, taking her bowl and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.1:4.4: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Blind Man’s Wood seeking seclusion.
sn5.1:4.5: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Āḷavikā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from seclusion,
sn5.1:4.6: went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.1:5.2: so what will seclusion do for you?
sn5.1:5.3: Enjoy the delights of sensual pleasure;
sn5.1:6.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.1:6.4: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from seclusion!”
sn5.1:6.5: Then Āḷavikā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.1:7.1: “There is an escape in the world,
sn5.1:7.2: and I’ve personally experienced it with wisdom.
sn5.1:7.3: O Wicked One, kinsman of the negligent,
sn5.1:8.1: Sensual pleasures are like swords and stakes;
sn5.1:8.2: the aggregates are their chopping block.
sn5.1:9.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Āḷavikā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
